PM11:09am

PM11:09am

Here's James Smith from ING

11:09 am
PM11:09am

Whilst we expect the Bank of England to hike rates in November, we think a lack of domestically-generated inflation means that any subsequent tightening will be limited

At 3%, September’s UK inflation rate is the highest it has been in five years and will continue to test the patience of the hawks at the Bank of England. But the key question is how much of this spike is domestically-enerated.

Well, firstly the latest headline figures were boosted by a 2.1% pick-up in fuel costs as pump prices respond to the recent increase in oil prices. But more importantly, it is clear that the impact of the pound’s post-Brexit plunge is still very much at play. Food prices, which are highly influenced by import costs, increased sharply by 0.8% on the month

PM11:09am

But neither of these factors tell us much about underlying momentum in prices. One way of stripping out these drivers is to look solely at the basket of goods that have a low import content (less than 20%) – and by this measure, inflation would actually be below target if the impact of sterling and energy are ignored.

It’s likely to be a similar story in tomorrow’s jobs report. Wage growth – a crucial input into the Bank’s decision making process – is likely to dip back to 2% and we think is likely to stay at, or below, this level for the next few months.

It’s also worth noting that this is probably about as high as inflation will go. We may see a slight pick-up to 3.1% in October, but thereafter headline CPI should gradually start to ease back.

So whilst we think a November rate hike is highly likely, for now we think the lack of domestically generated inflation combined with a sluggish growth outlook (and don’t forget all the noise surrounding Brexit) mean that any subsequent tightening is likely to be very limited.

PM11:10am

And some Barclays

11:10 am
PM11:10am

Upside contributors were concentrated within volatile headline and core components, including food & non-alcoholic beverages, transport costs and recreational & culture. Elsewhere within the basket, several non-energy industrial goods and services prices contributed negatively. In particular, clothing and footwear, education (largely as a result of base effects) and miscellaneous goods and services prices. Clothing and footwear in particular looks set to remain volatile in the coming months, with major retailers having held mid-season sales in October.

· The British Gas Electricity price hike was not captured by the September data, meaning it will feed through to October inflation, in line with our previous assumptions.

PM11:10am

Inflation pressure remains in the pipeline. PPI input inflation accelerated to 8.4% y/y, unchanged since the August print revised up from a previously reported 7.6%. This corroborates with reported firming input price pressures in the latest round of PMIs, suggesting that even though near-term inflationary pressure should be contained risks are starting to tilt to the upside.

· The 3.0% y/y CPI print is firmer than the BoE central staff forecast in the August Inflation Report. It was insufficiently firm to trigger an exchange of open letters between the BoE Governor and the Chancellor of the Exchequer. Given the release was close to market expectations, it does little to change the near-term monetary policy outlook in our opinion. We continue to expect the BoE to hike rates by 25bp at the November MPC meeting.

· RPI was close to our sub-consensus forecast. As we expected, base effects from volatility in estimated mortgage interest rate costs caused the RPI-CPI basis to contract in September.

PM11:22am

Actually, let me share some Merlin grey before moving on

PM11:23am

Liberum has gone under review

PM11:23am

Summer trading has been worse than our low end expectations with LFL sales growth slowing across all three divisions to 0.3% for the group – we were expecting 2.4% and consensus 3.2%. Current trading remains mixed with London likely to remain subdued for the foreseeable future. This has led to a rethink of capex allocation and some additional cost cutting, with EBITDA for the year expected to be in the range £470m to £480m against our current expectations for £478m. Consensus stood at £491m prior to announcement, so while our numbers don’t move significantly there will be 3-4% consensus for FY17E year and 5-6% cuts for FY18E. The poor summer trading adds to our on-going concerns about the Midway division, the reallocation of capex away from the existing estate towards accommodation dilutes returns and the additional £262m required to build LEGOLAND New York delays returns visibility yet further. The risk/reward profile has shifted more to the downside. Given this and the sharp share price reaction this morning, we place our recommendation and TP under-review pending the presentation at 9.30am.

11:24 am
PM11:24am

And Shore

PM11:24am

Merlin Entertainments has this morning issued a trading update for the 40 weeks ended 7th October 2017 which will disappoint investors, EBITDA for the full year is expected to be £470-£480m, which compares to a consensus range of £478-505m.

The impact of the terror attacks should be well understood by the market, with this coming through at the interim results in August in terms of domestic visitors, with only the impact of the longer lead time overseas visitors being unknown at this point. However, in addition a number of other issues have compounded trading concerns, which include the closure of LEGOLAND Florida for a number of days due to hurricanes (shouldn’t be a surprise) but post re-opening local visitor numbers have been sluggish, while in Resort Theme Parks as well as a UK terror related drop in visitor numbers, flash flooding in Italy saw Gardaland visitor numbers down sharply on a number of days, while generally poor weather has apparently also played a part in dampening visitor numbers across the estate.

We believe it is fair to consider the relatively small level of EBITDA downgrade as a positive reflection on the overall resilience of the business model and group. Although it is also fair to say that unfortunately for the foreseeable future terror related disruption must be considered the new normal and longer term expectations must be adjusted to reflect this.

PM11:26am

Views post profit warning: Less than one year after its IPO, the company
has managed to substantially underdeliver its own growth projections (2017
organic sales growth guidance cut from

4% to c1-2%) and to disappoint

investors on the delivery of the key margin improvement program (MIP). On
our estimates, close to 60% of our 2019E operating earnings cut is due to
reduced sales in the higher margin Wound and Ostomy Care franchises,
where management admitted that it has lost orders as the company could not
deliver due to problems with manufacturing transfers. In an optimal case, the
lost MIP benefits, which management however sees unchanged at

300bps,

might be recuperated over time. However, management remained vague
about the future trajectory of such MIP gains, raising the possibility of further
investor disappointment, in our view. We newly model for 50bps/100bps
improvement in 2018/19E, but admittedly with rather limited confidence

11:34 am
PM11:35am

Molior London survey – As a reminder, the London Quarterly Sales
Report from Molior is a survey that interviews every development scheme
in London (excl. schemes with fewer than 20 private-sale homes) once a
quarter. In 3Q17, developers behind 655 scheme across London were
interviewed.

PM11:35am

Molior released its 3Q17 London residential report. Headline figures
report the level of unsold stock in the market, as at the end of 3Q17, has
increased to 28,400 units, up 15% from the end of 2016. The report notes
that the higher price brackets remain the main area of weakness, with
help to buy and build to rent helping support sales trends below £1,000
psf.

PM11:36am

Housing starts have outpaced sales for the 12th consecutive quarter –
The level of housing starts in 3Q17 was 7,766, whilst the number of sales
was 6,175. This marks the 12th consecutive quarter in which the level of
housing starts have outpaced sales (see Figure 2)
■ Level of unsold stock up 15% vs. end-2016 – Inner London market
accounts for 53% of unsold units, with outer accounting for 47%. The table
below demonstrates the significant increase in unsold stock at the higher
price points.

11:36 am
PM11:36am

CS saying this bodes badly for Berkeley

PM11:36am

Negative read to Berkeley Group (U/P, TP 2,985p) – we continue to cite
Berkeley Group as our key underperform. Berkeley has an unfavourably
high exposure to the inner London housing market (50% of active
developments in zones 1-3). Additionally, we note that Berkeley gross
margins have a strong negative correlation (c.-70%) with the level of
unsold new build stock in London. Given the 15% increase in unsold units
in 3Q17 (from 2016 end), we continue to expect the group to come under
gross margin pressure. Despite the obvious weakness in its underlying
market we note that Berkeley shares have not underperformed the wider
sector. The Group continues to trade on 2.2x our annualised 2018 TNAV.

11:43 am
PM11:43am

Bulls on Pearson may be reassured by management’s comments that Pearson’s US Higher Education Publishing revenues will be at the higher end of its +1% to -7% guidance. We think this is a mistake given their lack of visibility and Pearson’s previous form when it comes to guidance. Management suggest they are taking share in the US Higher Ed market, which we think is down to new editions. Also on the dividend, where their comments suggest that the dividend may be above market expectations if the results come in as guided to, we think there is a significant risk. Two questions / points particularly of note:

PM11:43am

1.

PM11:43am

On trading performance, should the market take the 9m or Q3 as the trend line going into Q4? Management’s comments were opaque but suggestions that 2H would be tough and 1H benefited from phasing / one-off suggesting more looking at the Q3 line. For Q3, Pearson stated that its North American underlying revenue performance was not -10% but, given 1H was flat and 9m was -4%, it cannot be much better and, while Pearson pointed to a one-off emergency contract in Tennessee, Pearson’s swerving of the question if US Higher Education revenues was down high single digit revenues (management only stated the revenues were flat).

11:43 am
PM11:44am

And 2

PM11:44am

There are no indications visibility has improved at Pearson. Looking at our conference call notes from last year, what struck us was just how management had no inkling of the 30% decline that would hit their US Higher Education publishing business in Q4 16. While they were at pains to point out this is a smaller contribution now, it is still high margin and high drop through of revenues to profits and so a repeat of Q4 16, even at a much lower impact rate than a 30% drop, would leave Pearson struggling on its guidance.

PM11:45am

And his sign off par

11:44 am
PM11:45am

What is likely to make this year more tricky in terms of returns is that this is a heavy year of new editions for Pearson in US Higher Education Publishing. In the last cycle, in 2014, Pearson’s results benefited from the last cycle of books and so it will able to predict fairly accurately the trends. The problem(s) this time round include radically changed student buying patterns and, a major unknown, major College bookstore chains who have a markedly less cordial relationship with Pearson

PM11:45am

On produciton

Rio Tinto PLC (RIO:LSE): Last: 3,712, down 6.5 (-0.17%), High: 3,745, Low: 3,698, Volume: 1.42m
PM11:54am

Production missed our estimates in high margin operations and beat in smaller lower margin assets. Guidance is a stretch in iron ore and downgraded in mined copper. We expect low single digit consensus downgrades but production is not a key driver of the shares. We remain Equal-weight.

11:54 am
PM11:54am

The 3Q production result is unlikely to trigger major changes in consensus earnings estimates or investments views we believe. The three main share price drivers are (1) value obtained for assets that are subject to a disposal process (2) developments around Grasberg which we value at USD3.4 billion for Rio Tinto's volume share and most importantly (3) re-investment of cash in new assets, in particular Amrun and Oyu Tolgoi phase 2.

PM11:55am

The two key capex projects, Amrun bauxite in Australia and Oyu Tolgoi phase 2 copper in Mongolia, are on track for first production in 1H 2019 and mid 2020 respectively. Both are currently on budget. No new projects were approved in 3Q. Exploration spending increased modestly YoY for the first time in a while to USD122mn (USD112mn in 2Q2016).

PM11:56am

PM11:59am

Corbyn’s continued momentum causes us to analyse the potential impact of a Labour government on UK PLCs. First we examine the likely market reaction to a Corbyn victory, noting a sharp de-rating in the FTSE 250 would be likely, and at the sector level; Utilities and Discretionary Retail could be most vulnerable. Next we provide four screens, ranging from tax beneficiaries to dollar earners. Finally, our analysts give an assessment of any stock-specific exposures to the Labour manifesto.

PM12:03pm

And because Airbus Bombadiar mentioned, here's their para on that as well

12:02 pm
PM12:03pm

Airbus will acquire a c.50% stake in the C Series programme in return for procurement, sales and marketing and customer support. Bombardier and Investissement Quebec will own c.30% and c.20% respectively. The transaction has been approved by both Boards and the Government of Quebec. Pending Toronto Stock Exchange approval Airbus will also receive warrants on 100m B shares in Bombardier, reflecting approximately 5% of the company’s issued A and B shares. This deal is a direct result of Boeing’s pursuit of protectionist measures against The C Series in the US; without the financial success of which Bombardier would likely face bankruptcy, so is something of an own goal for the US OEM, as due to Airbus’ Alabama plant which will conduct final assembly work on US-bound C Series, no import tariffs will be levied. The partnership brings together two complimentary product lines – with the C Series in the 100-150 seat market segment and Airbus focussing on sales of upgauged variants of its popular A320/321 narrowbody platform, with the A319 ceding to the C Series. Given ongoing OEM pricing, we expected some consolidation of tier 1 and 2 suppliers. This deal between two OEMS is likely to only increase that pressure, as it allows the C Series programme to leverage Airbus’ supply chain expertise. In our coverage, GKN remains a sell after last weeks profit warning (300p TP), as is Meggitt (375p TP).
